text: Protected by leather armour and a small shield, these former bandits brace for impact against cavalry charges.
Let our enemies know that we do not fear, and we do not falter.
These cavalry roll in like storm clouds, and strike with the force of lightning.
It takes a very steady hand, supreme patience, and expert timing to land a shot as accurately as these bowmen.
Hand-picked by the general, these seasoned shock-troops relentlessly batter enemy lines with all the fury of their namesake.
The dao is an elegant weapon. Simply made, for a simple purpose: death.
Soldiers armed with long-range crossbows powerful enough to pierce enemy armour and defences.
Highly-trained archers outfitted with leather armour and armed with zhibeidao swords to defend against infantry attacks.
Fighting on to the last, unafraid of any enemy, these warriors are the bane of presumptuous heroes.
Fearless bandits unafraid to brace themselves against heavy cavalry and pierce horses’ armour with their long qiang spears.
To live, for these warriors, is to fight, even though the cause is long past.
It is often the thud of crossbow bolts into the enemy that signals the onset of battle.
Leaving behind the fields to swell the ranks, these peasants are armed with long spears to defend against cavalry charges.
Foes may survive the blowpipe attack only to fall under the blades of the machetes.
The vast imperial palatial grounds are defended by many warriors and none more fearsome than the sword-wielding cavalry guard.
Sometimes brute strength and relentless force will win the day.
Martial arts training has given these warriors unmatched stamina and made them experts users of the staff for attacking and defending.
Though not yet as potent as their elite cousins, the cubs are no less powerful in themselves.
Archers equipped with composite bows for long-range harassment of enemies and basic zhibeidao swords for close combat defence.
All will fight in the defence of their leader, but others will fight all the more fiercely to avenge them.
The oppressed, although coerced into service by the Han dynasty, will gladly turn their weapons back on their former masters.
Spears in hand, the indomitable defenders of the north stand resolute.
Let the thunder of hooves rise and fall like a summer storm, and be gone just as swiftly.
Be they man or monster, no one can withstand the thundering force of not one, but many, ten-foot bolts.
Fearless heralds of the Yellow Sky, whose powerful charge strikes down all who would oppose the Great Peace.
A sabre, and warrior, trained by the Han, raised by the Han, and now blooded by them.
Elite archers hand-picked by the emperor for their versatility and excellence.
Those the Han call barbarians are just warriors determinedly defending their home against invaders.
Armoured cavalry archers who harass the enemy with arrows while using their mounts to remain out of reach.
Tribal horsemen whose ferocity and unrelenting attacks on exposed flanks are matched only by their riding skills.
Strength and courage are not everything; sometimes speed makes all the difference, and this marauding cavalry has very fast horses.
With a short spear in each hand, the chosen warriors stride forth, uncaring of the danger, towards destiny.
Peace can only be attained through struggle and strife - a pair of axes are helpful in this regard.
Infantry-for-hire that can easily weather hot climates. They are used to capture key strategic points on the battlefield.
Against the toughest armour, a crossbow bolt will still slow you down. Against the defenceless, however…
The message the Yellow Turbans deliver is one of justice over corruption, with thundering hooves and furious charge.
Hold the bow steady, and don't hesitate. This is no pig you're skewering, friend.
These men have basic weapons, and determination in droves. But that's essentially all they have.
These infantry protect the flanks; their shields guard against enemy missiles, while enemy cavalry skewer themselves on their spears.
Infantry armed with polearms to pierce the armour of heavy cavalry, while their armour protects them against enemy missiles.
Hurling large, heavy projectiles to breach enemy defences from afar requires quite a feat of engineering.
The charge? Oh the charge is only the beginning…
A people only truly die the last time their name is spoken. Until then, they live on.
Seizing their only chance for glory, these mounted peasants charge headlong into foes and chase down fleeing enemies.
The peasants, born from nothing into nothing, will see this rebellion won.
They may not be trained in the formal ways of war, but battle will teach them... or not.
Do not be fooled by the length of those spears: they can still be thrown.
The leaders of the land are tainted by corruption, and must be cleansed with steel.
The best riders are rewarded with iron armour to maximise their devastating flanking charge.
If they do not yet fear us, they will soon learn to.
Years of banditry have enabled these troops to sneak behind enemy lines, striking at unsuspecting foes and capturing strategic points.
When they had no home or purpose, the White Tiger provided. Now they will defend both.
The Yellow Turbans must be sword and shield both, holding back the tide of corruption whilst simultaneously pushing it back.
Personally selected by the emperor, these heavily-armoured warriors are the vanguard of the frontline.
Elite warriors whose belief and commitment to the Way inspires others and gives extra weight to the swing of their twin sabres.
These elite troops’ armour protects them in close combat, enabling them to fight when not using their long-range, armour-piercing crossbows.
A bow is simple to use and difficult to master. Luckily, mastery is not a requirement of participation.
To these renowned warriors, the lance is simply a lethal extension of the arm.
A flying axe can ruin your whole day.
Few have the skills to master the ancient fighting style of the jian sword while parrying blows with a shield.
Well-trained armoured infantry, carrying rattan shields and zhibeidao swords for close combat with enemy infantry.
Little strikes fear into an enemy like a hail of arrows blocking out the sun.
A power contained is not a power tamed; this tribal fury can now simply be directed where its master desires.
Movement is its own form of strength. What this unit may lack in armour it makes up for in versatility.
Peasant militia armed with polearms; an expendable but versatile main force on the frontlines.
The charge that once bolstered the Han now rides against them, sabres drawn, in the name of the Yellow Sky.
The greatest warriors of one of the greatest leaders of the Nanman.
These spearmen are trained to hold the line, thrusting out at any who would oppose them, or their lord!
Ride. Fire. Feign retreat. Repeat.
Archers equipped with composite bows for long-range harassment of enemies and basic zhibeidao swords for close combat defence.
Light, manoeuvrable cavalry can create chaos and confusion in the enemy ranks and, ultimately, victory.
There are powers in the mountains – you are all that holds them back.
Devotees to the Great Peace who raise the spirits of their fighting allies with Taoist chants and incantations.
Prince Liu Chong seeks to make a safe land for all. His royal guard will see that vision realised.
Complete victory only comes from ruthless determination, usually found at the end of a blade.
These cavalry troops are armed with zhibeidao swords to neutralise archers and combat enemy cavalry units alike.
The quarry of these mounted archers was once waterfowl, but is now considerably larger, which only makes for an easier target.
The axe is one of the few weapons well-suited to both missile and melee combat.
No matter the size of the hunter's prey, a well-aimed dart tipped with a sufficiently strong poison can take them down.
Heavily-armoured infantry that hold the main battle line with polearms from Yuan Shao’s personal armoury.
These archers excel at harassing enemy troops, but are unafraid of charging into the melee if needed.
Generations of warriors have served with pride and fury in the household cavalry. It is an institution beyond repute.
With ji polearms thrust ahead, these cavalry troops break enemy lines with a headlong charge.
This infantry gathers equipment dropped or left behind in battle to help their brothers and sisters continue the fight.
If the initial charge does not break the foe, the follow-up soon will.
These elite, battle-hardened bandits carry an axe in each hand, and advance ahead of the front lines to catch their foes unawares
These former bandits obey a greater law and lend their sabres and hard-fought experience to the Yellow Turban cause.
With a tally of many victories between them, this armoured infantry form the vanguard of the frontline with sword and shield.
Banditry is a simple profession – wade into battle with whichever weapon you find, and take everything you can.
Though their origins may be humble, the warriors of the Nanman can hold their own.
Put a spear in these men's hands and they will fight. Against all odds, for their homes, they will fight…
Cavalry troops that rely on the speed of their mounts to charge into lightly-armoured enemies and chase down fleeing enemies.
Clad in full armour, these elite cavalry troops deflect arrows with their shields as they bear down on their enemies.
The swing of a dao, from horseback, is the last thing many see before their head is cleaved from their neck.
These mounted troops hunt down skirmishers; protecting against missiles with shields and using zhibeidao swords to chop at the enemy.
These troops have been selected for their skill in the ancient fighting style with the jian sword - a deadly weapon when mastered.
Veteran rebels armed with a sabre, shield and a swift, strong charge.
Let our foes advance. They will soon feel the bite of our blades.
Nomads, masters of cavalry, know exactly how, and where, to deploy their armoured horses for maximum devastation.
Well-trained infantry using powerful crossbows at long range, but also skilled with armour and shield in close combat.
To lead where others follow is the domain of the truly elite.
Seasoned shock cavalry whose speed and powerful charge make them perfect for battering enemy lines before withdrawing to strike again.
The infantry of Jing are charged by Liu Biao to guard the flanks against enemy missiles and brace their spears against cavalry charges.
For the crime of defying the Han, the Yellow Turbans offer a choice much preferable to the barbaric 'justice' of the state.
To kill a man? That's one thing. But to kill an animal? That seems another cruel business altogether.
Onyx Dragons are as adept at swinging their blades as pulling their bows; elite and versatile infantry.
Stand firm, friends. We will show you how it's done!
The horse is made only more terrifying by cladding it in armour and directing it at the enemy.
These lancers were trained and drilled by the Han's military machine. Now they turn their weapons against their former masters.
Cavalry troops who fight only for gold; excellent at capturing key strategic points and fighting in hot climates.
Bravery drives a warrior to battle more effectively than any general; a good spear and shield keeps them there.
Can any warrior stand against a charging elephant?
Tribal archers who excel at skirmishing due to their accuracy, endless endurance and long polearms to counter enemy cavalry assaults.
The men of the south have always fought to protect what they hold dear.
Clad in iron, these warriors use robust tower shields to defend and hold the line at all costs.
After years of ambushing traders, these former bandits now train their arrows on the oppressors of the land.
In defence of the emperor, there is no lengths to which these soldiers would not go.
In defence of the emperor, there are no lengths to which these soldiers would not go.
Skilled militia armed with polearms and bows, a flexible and effective unit for combat both close and from afar.
With the bruising mace and the burning fire, the foe is soon dealt with.
There is, it would seem, no better plan than to do or to die.
A phalanx of spears will see off most enemies.
The tiger is the lord of beasts. In war, the mere sight of such a creature can unman the bravest warrior.
When you fight to live, you tend to become exceedingly good at it.
These elite soldiers are armed with long-range crossbows powerful enough to pierce armour.
Equipped with partial iron armour and highly-protective shields, these disciplined elite cavalry hunt down enemies armed with missile weapons.
These troops are armed with fast-loading, repeating crossbows to quickly shoot down their foes.
Infantry-for-hire, they easily weather hot climates and are best used to capture key strategic points on the battlefield.
With spears thrust to the fore, these iron-clad warriors target armoured enemies.
At the gates of the imperial palace, these warriors stand, guarding the emperor with steel brandished!
These troops' rapid-firing repeating crossbows lay waste to scores of enemies, while iron armour protects them against retaliatory fire.
In the name of the cause they lost, the fight will continue, no matter how hopeless.
In the service of their lady, these warriors will never yield to their enemies.
Elite cavalry guards who have turned their weapons against their former masters to serve the Yellow Turbans.
What the cavalry charge begins, the sabre will surely finish.
In the defence of their prince, these warriors shall ride to whatever end.
Masters of defence who wield jian swords and rattan shields to hold the line against almost all enemies.
With lances lowered and locked, these cavalrymen charge into battle for their emperor and the realm.
Assault infantry armed with zhibeidao swords to break enemy spear lines.
From above, tucked between battlements and leering from gatehouses, the palace crossbowmen brook no quarter for the enemies of the empire.
When the cause is all you know, you proclaim it to everyone you meet, even your enemies in battle.
Arid heat has no effect on the performance or accuracy of these archers, who excel in capturing key strategic points.
When a tiger leads the charge, foes rarely look beyond the fearsome beast – which may be their last mistake!
Swift movement and deadly action are the essence of war. These warriors are fast as lightning, and just as lethal.
The imposing bulk of this elite infantry gives their swung maces the power of a gale, scattering their enemies before them.
Armoured former palace guards who use ji polearms raided from their previous masters in the fight for the Great Peace.
Trained in the tradition of nomadic horsemen, the speed and power of this cavalry’s charge scatter all before it.
With low morale and armed only with improvised clubs, these starving peasants may not be formidable, but they are many!
Arid heat has no effect on the performance or accuracy of these archers, who excel in capturing key strategic points.
Nature must be preserved and the world saved. These warriors will see it done.
Warriors chosen for the bravery needed to charge headlong into the enemy, polearms thrust to the fore.
With spears thrust to the fore, these iron-clad warriors target armoured enemies.
Do not doubt the efficacy of a barrage of well-aimed sling-shots.
These troops are so well armed that the most valued strategic locations should be entrusted to their defence.
Every gate is its own defence, but further held by the imposing, armoured gate guards.
Let the rattle of countless sabres presage war's coming.
Elite spear infantry hand-picked by Liu Biao to defend and hold the line behind their robust tower shields.
High blood drumming on the skin. They're on the hunt…
The empire is above all, imbued with the will of heaven. It will be defended!
As though elephants were not mighty enough, these beasts have even more power!
They dart in, self assured and sure-footed, pelt the enemy, and are gone.
Heavily-armoured troops carrying long-range crossbows powerful enough to pierce enemy armour.
The cream of Shamoke's forces.
There can be no mercy for treason. Justice will be delivered at the end of these warriors' spears.
Infantry as stalwart and unshakable as the mountains themselves.
In defence of their lands, the Nanman muster their spears.
These warriors will raise their halberds once more, if not for their cause then for themselves.
Fearless bandits armed with axes and composite bows; accuracy is less vital when you can sneak up on the enemy.
Battle has not dulled these blades, nor the resolves of their bearers.
A concerted volley of arrows is bad enough. When the arrows are on fire, it is time to run.
A crossbow is an effective and deadly weapon. So, too, a horse.
Archers with an unerring eye; their arrows rarely miss their targets.
Heavily-armoured masters of the polearm, these warriors hold the main battle line.
Elite infantry who cross all terrain types with ease, only to furiously attack enemy infantry with their axes.
Hardened by the bandit life, the furious charge of these axe-swinging troops is deadly to enemy infantry.
The Old Master helped define the way. In his name, these warriors will see the world set right.
Masters of defence who wield jian swords and rattan shields to hold the line against almost all enemies.
There is no battle line, no formation, that these warriors cannot see put to ruin.
A good axe and a strong arm are as good as any spear, sword or bow.
Elite warriors that parry and block projectiles with polearms before answering with a devastating charge.
These spears hold fast against whatever lies beyond that misted, dotted line.
Warriors chosen for the bravery needed to charge headlong into the enemy, polearms thrust to the fore.
Cheap to raise, but low in morale, these peasants are armed with only a simple bow and the will to fight for the promise of the Yellow Sky.
At the head of charge they draw their spears, driving home with a righteous cry!
These archers’ long siyah horn bows increase the velocity of their arrows, while they fend off attackers with zhibeidao swords.
To break these warriors is the challenge of many an army. So far, very few have succeeded.
Few have the skills to master the ancient fighting style of the jian sword while parrying blows with a shield.
Shamans who can take many blows before they fall, striking fear into the hearts of foes who believe they possess supernatural powers.
These swordsmen take the fight to the enemy in the name of their prince!
At the centre of the line, weapons extended, these warriors do not - cannot - flinch. Their resolve, implacable.
Highly-trained bowmen who excel when unleashing rapid volleys of arrows to slow and supress cavalry charges.
The south, they say, is full of tigers, so one should take care where they wander.
The reach of these warriors extends and contracts; accuracy with the bow and spear targets distant and nearby enemies alike.
Selected by Yuan Shao, the Warriors of Ye are protected by iron armour and use their polearms to pierce heavy cavalry's armour.
Yang Feng expects his troops to be the best, and he will not be disappointed.
placeholder
When the fight comes to them, these javelineers are too canny to leave themselves defenceless.
The lighter the armour, the faster the warrior, the quicker the strike, the sooner the kill.
Forsaking farming tools for sharpened bamboo stakes, these peasants are cheap, with low morale, but risk their lives to fight against oppression.
Former poachers renowned for their stealth and skill with the bow, making them excellent ambushers.
Hand-picked by Gongsun Zan, these elite cavalry archers ride white horses and harass enemies while remaining out of reach.
Merchants and craftsmen armed with looted sabres and armour, fuelled by a righteous fury against injustice.
To truly hunt with the spear is to let it become an extension of your body, in turn making you a lethal opponent in battle.
Cavalry troops who fight only for gold; excellent at capturing key strategic points and fighting in hot climates.
The Xianbei were infamous, feared for their lightning-fast attacks and ceaseless harassment of their foes.
Hand-picked by Gongsun Zan, these elite cavalry archers ride white horses and harass enemies while remaining out of reach.
War is a messy affair, often coming down not to who is best, but who is luckiest.
The men of the south have always fought to protect what they hold dear.
The Tao is the eternal quest for enlightenment. War may not aid that quest, but it's a necessary evil all the same.
Merciless tribal cavalry, crashing into enemies with a devastating charge and dispatching any survivors with swords.
Stealthy and skilled, when their spears strike true, expect pain.
Theirs are the spears that guard the realm of Han.
The cragged edges of the southern mountains fashion peasants into warriors, flint-eyed and sharp.
Patience, focus and resolve; the skills of the poacher are perfectly transferable to the needs of the battlefield.
When you hunt to live, silence becomes your ally, and your bow skills become… considerable.
A glaive is a most powerful weapon, and zealotry more powerful still.
In case the foe survives a charging elephant, the Ravine Warriors follow in the beasts' wake, a weapon in each hand.
Many enemies fall to the jian blades of these elite, heavily-armoured swordsmen defending the line in service of Yuan Shu.
The 'yaoguai' demons move unseen and strike with a lethality that is scarcely believable.
Zheng Jiang arms her fiercest bandits with fu axes and deploys them to charge into enemy infantry.
Any army that marches with elephants already have superiority when it comes to morale.
Those from beyond our borders may seem strange, but if they fight well it is better that they are on our side.
It is an irony above all that arrows fletched by the dynasty to destroy rebels should now be turned back on them.
